causes: British efforts to control the Gold Coast and Asante trade routes.
Asante Empire's military expansion and resistance to colonial influence.
Conflicts over trade in gold, slaves, and resources.
events_leading_up_to_war: British and Dutch trading companies clashed with Asante merchants in the late 1700s.
The British abolished the transatlantic slave trade in 1807, weakening Asante economy.
British private military companies and mercenaries were hired to reinforce colonial control.

result.general: British victory; Asante Empire weakened and eventually annexed.

treaties.name: Treaty of Fomena
terms: Asante Empire forced to pay indemnities to Britain.
British gained more control over Gold Coast trade routes.

treaties.name: Annexation of Asante
terms: Asante fully incorporated into the British Gold Coast colony.
British imposed direct rule over former Asante territories.

territorial_changes: Asante territory lost sovereignty, becoming a British protectorate.
British expanded control over West African trade and resources.

entities: Allied African states resisting British influence
allies: Various Akan states supporting Asante resistance

entities: British private military companies (PMC) and mercenaries
allies: West African Fante Confederation (rival group to Asante)

private_military_companies_and_mercenari.name: African Company of Merchants
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.role: Operated private military forces in the Gold Coast.
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.tactics: Used local militia, European mercenaries, and fortifications for defense.

private_military_companies_and_mercenari.name: West India Regiments
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.role: British-hired African soldiers trained in European tactics.
private_military_companies_and_mercenari.tactics: Used in jungle warfare and urban combat.

Asante_Empire: King Kofi Karikari (faced British invasion in 1874)
British_Empire: Major General Sir Garnet Wolseley (1873-74 campaign leader)
Sir Robert Baden-Powell (military leader in later campaigns)

Asante_Empire.tactics: Ambush warfare, extensive use of fortifications, reliance on iron and brass artillery.

British_Empire.navy: Royal Navy warships used for coastal bombardment.
British_Empire.tactics: European-style line infantry formations, scorched-earth policies, and use of Gatling guns.

Asante_Empire.dead_and_wounded: Tens of thousands, including high-ranking nobles.
Asante_Empire.destruction: Major cities like Kumasi were burned down.

British_Empire.dead_and_wounded: Several thousand British and African troops.
British_Empire.destruction: Fortified British outposts were occasionally overrun.

major_battles.name: Battle of Nsamankow
major_battles.description: Asante forces decisively defeated British troops, killing Governor Charles MacCarthy.
major_battles.outcome: Asante victory, but led to long-term British retaliation.

major_battles.name: Sack of Kumasi
major_battles.description: British forces invaded and burned the Asante capital, forcing them into submission.
major_battles.outcome: British victory, leading to the Treaty of Fomena.

major_battles.name: War of the Golden Stool
major_battles.description: Final Asante rebellion led by Queen Mother Yaa Asantewaa.
major_battles.outcome: Asante defeated, leading to full British annexation.

texts.name: Asante Chronicles
texts.author: Asante royal court scribes
texts.details: Records traditional Asante perspectives on the wars.

texts.name: British Colonial Reports
texts.author: British administrators
texts.details: Documents military campaigns and trade disputes.

archaeological_evidence.description: Burned remains of Asante capital city after British invasion.
Asante bronze artillery and European rifles used in battles.
